My team has had some problems with energy chain this year. We found that Igus is expensive and the ordering process was slow and glitchy. WCP seemed to be out of stock. We just need to run 1 motor’s worth (2-10 gauge, 2 can wires, 2 sets of pwn) so ideally small and with small bend radius.
Just wondering what brands people normally use.

  • Igus
  • Amazon
  • WCP
  • McMaster
  • Other
0 voters

Also wondering which type people use.

  • Inner Radius Openable
  • Outer Radius Openable
  • Non-openable
  • Other

Two key things to succeed with energy chains:
Use guide troughs/plates as much as possible
Attach to a couple of links, NOT just the end link.

Since our robots see 10+ g acceleration repeatedly and in all directions, we tend to tear off our chain mountings! At least half the robots you see with chains will have one or both mounting broken… You really want to have guides on both the moving and fixed parts that control as much of the chain as possible; think in terms of trapping it. You don’t need 100%, but do try to trap on three sides for each guide, and use some tapers and radii to help the chain enter and leave the trough.

oof. E-chain has been the biggest thorn in the side of FRC electrical teams for years (before that it was jags). You aren’t alone here.

1732 had success last year just ziptying elevator wires down to a thin, flexible polycarb strip, and mounting that strip the same way you’d normally mount e-chain. The upside is that the polycarb is happy to twist a little, while e-chain only wants to move perfectly up and down. The downsides are that the wires aren’t protected on all sides, and it’s more wiggly than e-chain.

1732 considered using the polycarb sheet technique again, but we went with e-chain. The kids made that decision, I don’t remember their exact reasoning. I do suspect that e-chain’s rigidity makes it better for this year’s tall, fast-moving elevators.
